authors.name: Geoffrey Hinton
authors.description: Considered the "Godfather of AI" for his foundational work on backpropagation and neural networks.

authors.name: Yann LeCun
authors.description: Inventor of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), which revolutionized computer vision.

authors.name: Yoshua Bengio
authors.description: A leading researcher in unsupervised learning, generative models, and neural language models.

authors.name: Demis Hassabis
authors.description: Co-founder of DeepMind, led projects like AlphaGo and AlphaFold, merging neuroscience and AI.

authors.name: Andrew Y. Ng
authors.description: Co-founder of Google Brain and Coursera, making AI education accessible to millions.

authors.name: Fei-Fei Li
authors.description: Creator of the ImageNet dataset, a catalyst for the deep learning revolution in computer vision.

authors.name: Jürgen Schmidhuber
authors.description: His lab developed Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, crucial for sequence analysis.

authors.name: Ian Goodfellow
authors.description: Inventor of Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), which transformed generative AI.

authors.name: Alex Krizhevsky
authors.description: Developed AlexNet, whose 2012 ImageNet victory ignited the deep learning revolution.

authors.name: Ilya Sutskever
authors.description: Co-founder of OpenAI and a key contributor to breakthroughs from AlexNet to ChatGPT.

authors.name: Andrej Karpathy
authors.description: Former Director of AI at Tesla, known for his influential work in computer vision and deep learning education.

authors.name: Michael I. Jordan
authors.description: A leading figure at the intersection of statistics and machine learning, grounding the field in statistical theory.

authors.name: Bernhard Schölkopf
authors.description: A leading researcher known for his work on support vector machines (SVMs), kernel methods, and causality.

authors.name: Vladimir Vapnik
authors.description: Co-inventor of the support vector machine (SVM) and a founder of statistical learning theory.

authors.name: Richard S. Sutton
authors.description: A primary founder of modern reinforcement learning, co-author of its foundational textbook.

authors.name: David Silver
authors.description: Lead researcher on AlphaGo at DeepMind, combining deep neural networks with reinforcement learning.

authors.name: John von Neumann
authors.description: Defined the Von Neumann architecture and made major contributions to game theory with applications in biology.

authors.name: Alan Turing
authors.description: A founder of computer science who also published influential work on mathematical biology and morphogenesis.

authors.name: Ronald L. Rivest
authors.description: Co-inventor of the RSA algorithm with significant contributions in computational biology and bioinformatics.

authors.name: Adi Shamir
authors.description: Co-inventor of the RSA algorithm, a cornerstone of modern internet security.

authors.name: Leonard M. Adleman
authors.description: Co-inventor of the RSA algorithm and a pioneer in the field of DNA computing.

authors.name: Jennifer Doudna
authors.description: Co-inventor of CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing technology, a groundbreaking tool for editing genomes.

authors.name: Emmanuelle Charpentier
authors.description: Co-inventor of CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing, sharing the Nobel Prize with Doudna.

authors.name: Frederick Sanger
authors.description: Two-time Nobel laureate in Chemistry who developed the first method for DNA sequencing.

authors.name: Alec Jeffreys
authors.description: Inventor of DNA fingerprinting, revolutionizing forensic science and paternity testing.

authors.name: Svante Pääbo
authors.description: Pioneered the field of paleogenomics, sequencing the Neanderthal genome.

authors.name: Shinya Yamanaka
authors.description: Discovered how to reprogram adult cells into induced pluripotent stem cells (iPS cells).

authors.name: Eric Lander
authors.description: A principal leader of the Human Genome Project.

authors.name: Francis Collins
authors.description: A leader of the Human Genome Project and former Director of the NIH.

authors.name: J. Craig Venter
authors.description: Pioneered new techniques for gene sequencing, including the shotgun sequencing approach for the human genome.

authors.name: Victor Ambros
authors.description: Co-discoverer of microRNA (miRNA), revealing a new layer of gene regulation.

authors.name: Gary Ruvkun
authors.description: Co-discoverer of microRNA (miRNA) and its role in regulating gene expression.

authors.name: Elizabeth Blackburn
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the discovery of how telomeres and the enzyme telomerase protect chromosomes.

authors.name: Kary Mullis
authors.description: Inventor of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR), a fundamental technique in molecular biology.

authors.name: Barbara McClintock
authors.description: Nobel laureate for her discovery of transposable elements or "jumping genes".

authors.name: Andrew Z. Fire
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the co-discovery of RNA interference (RNAi).

authors.name: Craig C. Mello
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the co-discovery of RNA interference (RNAi).

authors.name: Joanne Chory
authors.description: Pioneered the use of genetic analysis to study how plants respond to light and hormones.

authors.name: Kevin McKernan
authors.description: A pioneer in genomics and DNA sequencing, known for his work on the Human Genome Project and cannabis genomics.

authors.name: Ada E. Yonath
authors.description: Nobel laureate for elucidating the atomic structure of the ribosome, the cell's protein factory.

authors.name: Yoshinori Ohsumi
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his discoveries of mechanisms for autophagy, the cell's recycling process.

authors.name: James W. Black
authors.description: Nobel laureate who developed a rational, targeted approach to drug design, inventing beta-blockers.

authors.name: Tu Youyou
authors.description: Nobel laureate for discovering Artemisinin, a key drug for treating malaria, inspired by traditional Chinese medicine.

authors.name: David Baltimore
authors.description: Nobel laureate for co-discovering reverse transcriptase and his work on tumor viruses.

authors.name: Stanley Cohen
authors.description: Nobel laureate for co-discovering Nerve Growth Factor (NGF) and Epidermal Growth Factor (EGF).

authors.name: Rita Levi-Montalcini
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the discovery of Nerve Growth Factor (NGF).

authors.name: Katalin Karikó
authors.description: Nobel laureate whose foundational research on mRNA modifications enabled COVID-19 vaccines.

authors.name: Drew Weissman
authors.description: Nobel laureate who, with Katalin Karikó, developed the modified mRNA technology used in COVID-19 vaccines.

authors.name: Raphael Mechoulam
authors.description: Often called the 'father of cannabis research' for isolating THC and elucidating the endocannabinoid system.

authors.name: Lumir Hanus
authors.description: A Czech chemist who, with William Devane, isolated the first known endocannabinoid, anandamide.

authors.name: Vincenzo Di Marzo
authors.description: A leading researcher on the endocannabinoid system, its role in physiology, and its pharmacological modulation.

authors.name: Bert Vogelstein
authors.description: A pioneer in cancer genetics who elucidated the molecular basis of colorectal cancer.

authors.name: Robert Langer
authors.description: An extremely prolific bioengineer, a pioneer of drug delivery systems and tissue engineering.

authors.name: Salim Yusuf
authors.description: Cardiologist who has led some of the largest and most influential global clinical trials in cardiovascular disease.

authors.name: Luc Montagnier
authors.description: Nobel laureate for co-discovering the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).

authors.name: Françoise Barré-Sinoussi
authors.description: Nobel laureate for her role in the discovery of HIV as the cause of AIDS.

authors.name: Robert Gallo
authors.description: Contributed significantly to the identification of HIV and developed the first HIV test.

authors.name: César Milstein
authors.description: Nobel laureate who, with Georges Köhler, devised the hybridoma technique for monoclonal antibodies.

authors.name: Ian Wilmut
authors.description: Led the team that cloned the first mammal from an adult cell, the sheep Dolly.

authors.name: Godfrey Hounsfield
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his part in developing the diagnostic technique of X-ray computed tomography (CT).

authors.name: James P. Allison
authors.description: Nobel laureate for discovering immune checkpoint therapy for cancer.

authors.name: Tasuku Honjo
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his identification of the protein PD-1, leading to new cancer immunotherapies.

authors.name: Shizuo Akira
authors.description: An immunologist who made seminal discoveries in innate immunity, particularly regarding Toll-like receptors (TLRs).

authors.name: Yasmine Belkaid
authors.description: Researches the complex interaction between the microbiome and the immune system.

authors.name: Mihai G. Netea
authors.description: Known for his concept of "trained immunity," showing that the innate immune system has memory.

authors.name: Karl Deisseroth
authors.description: A key developer of optogenetics, a technique to control neurons with light.

authors.name: Karl Friston
authors.description: Developed the influential "Free Energy Principle" theory of brain function and Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM) for fMRI analysis.

authors.name: Edvard I. Moser
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the co-discovery of grid cells, which form the brain's internal positioning system.

authors.name: May-Britt Moser
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the co-discovery of grid cells in the brain, crucial for spatial navigation.

authors.name: Frances H. Arnold
authors.description: Nobel laureate for pioneering the directed evolution of enzymes.

authors.name: Michael Grätzel
authors.description: Inventor of dye-sensitized solar cells (Grätzel cells) and a leader in perovskite solar cell research.

authors.name: Chad A. Mirkin
authors.description: A pioneer in nanotechnology, known for spherical nucleic acids (SNAs) and dip-pen nanolithography.

authors.name: Omar M. Yaghi
authors.description: A leader in the development of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and covalent organic frameworks (COFs).

authors.name: John B. Goodenough
authors.description: Nobel laureate for his critical contributions to the development of the lithium-ion battery.

authors.name: Charles M. Lieber
authors.description: A pioneer in nanoscience known for his work on nanowire sensors and their biological applications.

authors.name: Moungi Bawendi
authors.description: Nobel laureate for the discovery and synthesis of quantum dots.

authors.name: Johan Rockström
authors.description: Developed the "Planetary Boundaries" framework, defining safe operating spaces for humanity.

authors.name: Sandra Díaz
authors.description: An ecologist whose work on plant functional biodiversity is central to understanding ecosystem services.

authors.name: Corinne Le Quéré
authors.description: Leads the Global Carbon Project, providing authoritative annual analyses of the global carbon budget.

authors.name: Mario Molina
authors.description: Nobel laureate for identifying the threat to the ozone layer from chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) gases.

authors.name: Rattan Lal
authors.description: A leading soil scientist who has shown how healthy soils can sequester carbon to mitigate climate change.

authors.name: Jane Goodall
authors.description: Her long-term research on chimpanzees transformed our understanding of animal behavior and conservation.

authors.name: Pavel A. Pevzner
authors.description: A founding father of computational genomics, developing key algorithms for sequence assembly.

authors.name: Peer Bork
authors.description: A pioneer in the analysis of metagenomes, particularly the human microbiome.

authors.name: Fabian Theis
authors.description: A leader in applying AI and machine learning to analyze single-cell biological data.

authors.name: John Jumper
authors.description: Co-led the development of AlphaFold at DeepMind, which revolutionized protein structure prediction.
